response.answer_text: All of them professed some form of Christianity, though they might not have aligned with any particular denomination. Even Jefferson and Franklin styled themselves as Christians despite having problems with some doctrines like the Trinity and the Incarnation. They all appreciated religion’s positive role in American society. The good majority considered themselves Christian and were considered Christian at the time. The one major exception was probably Thomas Paine, who leaned more toward agnostic. Thomas Jefferson was a Diest, and John Adams and Ben Franklin were Unitarians. 200+ years ago, you could be a Diest or Unitarian and still be considered Christian. Since then, some Christians have narrowed the standards. What people like Jefferson, Adams, and Franklin believed was 1) there was some kind of cosmic God, but not necessarily one who performed miracles, 2) the surpassing wisdom of Jesus’ moral teachings, and 3) usually some possibility of an afterlife. But they did not accept the Trinity or Incarnation. Of the other Founding Fathers, they tended to belong to a “mainline” religious denomination but were generally not what we would call “Evangelicals” or “Fundamentalists” today. For example, George Washington was an Anglican (today he’d be Episcopalian), but questioned the literal truth of transubstantiation. He also believed strongly in religious freedom for all Americans.
